title: Why Families Used To Stay Together
description:
————————————————————
Ready to build a network of amazing women and high-status men?

social lives by becoming higher status.

Click this link to learn how you can have a High-Status lifestyle now:
https://m.moamentoring.com/podcast

channel_info.title: Michael Sartain
channel_info.description:
🎙Host of The Michael Sartain Podcast 

🔥Teaching you how to build a network of desirable women and high-status men

👇 Click the "Men of Action" link below now to forge a high-status lifestyle and join the elites

transcription: {"text": "Homo sapien life for in general throughout our history is a lifetime of polygamy interspersed with small periods of monogamy. That's generally how it has worked through our life. Even if it's a case where I am monogamous with one person, he ends up dying of cancer and then she ends up being monogamous with another person, you have different periods of monogamy. For the majority of human existence, it has not been one man and one woman together for 75 years. That is something that happened probably, you know, after the agricultural revolution. Definitely you saw it more during times like the Dust Bowl or the Great Depression where marriage was actually a function of lifesaving. I'm sure you guys have met families that have 14 kids or something like that. Death and childbirth, infant mortality, those kind of things caused families to stay together. I was reading one study that was talking about during the Great Depression, people were miserable in their marriages but did not get divorced because it was a function of life and death. The problem is now that function of life and death isn't there.
